sen.j: 大井神社（おおいじんじゃ）は、京都府亀岡市大井町にある神社である。
sen.e: Oi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Oi-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Oi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Oi-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Oi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Oi-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は郷社。
sen.e: It is a shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines)), and its old shrine ranking is village shrine.
It is a shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines)), and its old shrine ranking is designated as a village shrine.
It is a shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines)), and its old shrine ranking is designated as a village shrine.

sen.j: 木俣神・イチキシマヒメ・ツクヨミを祀る。
sen.e: It enshrines Kinomata no kami, Ichikishima-hime, and Tsukuyomi.
It enshrines Kinomata no kami, Ichikishima-hime, and Tsukuyomi.
It enshrines Kinomata no kami, Ichikishima-hime, and Tsukuyomi.

sen.j: 大堰川の鎮護の神として崇められている。
sen.e: It is worshipped as the guarding god of Oi-gawa River.
It is worshipped as the god guarding the Oi-gawa River.
It is worshipped as the god guarding the Oi-gawa River.
History
History
History

sen.j: 和銅3年（710年）、元明天皇の勅命によつて創建された。
sen.e: It was built In 710 under imperial command by Empress Genmei.
It was built In 710 under imperial command by Empress Genmei.
It was built In 710 under the imperial command of Empress Genmei.
sen.cmt: 現状だと、天皇が命令して皇后が創建したとも取れる。従って、”under imperial command by Empress Genmei.”→ “under the imperial command of Empress Genmei.”

sen.j: 伝承によれば、大宝 (日本)2年（702年）、御井神と市杵島姫命がカメの背に乗って大堰川を遡上し、保津の急流に乗れなかったのでコイに乗り換え、現在の亀岡市河原林町勝林島に上陸したという（その地にも同名の大井神社があり、同じ神を祀る）。
sen.e: Legend says that in 702, Mii no kami and Ichikishima Hime no Mikoto went up the Oi-gawa River on the back of a turtle, but could not ride the rapids of Hozu, so they moved to a carp and came on shore to current Shorinjima, Kawarabashi-cho, Kameoka City (There is a Oi-jinja Shrine with the same name, enshrining the same god).

Legend says that in 702, Mii no kami and Ichikishima Hime no Mikoto went up the Oi-gawa River on the back of a turtle, but could not ride the rapids of Hozu, so they moved onto a carp and came ashore to current Shorinjima, Kawarabashi-cho, Kameoka City (There is an Oi-jinja Shrine with the same name, enshrining the same god).

Legend says that in 702, Mii no kami and Ichikishima Hime no Mikoto went up the Oi-gawa River on the back of a turtle, but could not ride the rapids of Hozu, so they moved onto a carp and came ashore to current Shorinjima, Kawarabashi-cho, Kameoka City (There is an Oi-jinja Shrine with the same name, enshrining the same god).

sen.j: このことから、鯉が当社の神使とされ、当社の氏子は鯉を食べることを禁忌とし、端午の節句に鯉のぼりを上げることもない。
sen.e: Thus, carp is considered the messenger of god in this shrine, and the shrine parishioners consider eating carp a taboo and do not fly carp streamers for Boy's Day celebration.
Thus, carp is considered the messenger of the god in this shrine, and the shrine parishioners consider eating carp a taboo and do not fly carp streamers for Boy's Day celebration.
Thus, carp is considered the messenger of the god in this shrine, and the shrine parishioners consider eating carp a taboo and do not fly carp streamers for Boy's Day celebration.

sen.j: 現在の社殿は、兵火で焼失した後、天正12年（1584年）に豊臣秀吉の命によって再建されたものである。
sen.e: Current main building of the shrine was rebuilt in 1584 ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, after burning down in fire caused by war.
The current main building of the shrine was rebuilt in 1584, ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, after it had burnt down in a fire caused by war.
The current main building of the shrine was rebuilt in 1584, ordered by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, after it had burnt down in a fire caused by war.
Festivals
Festivals
Festivals

sen.j: 10月16日の例祭では、隣接する馬場で武者姿の氏子による競馬（くらべうま）が奉納される。
sen.e: At the annual festival on October 16, kurabeuma (horse racing) is presented at the horse-riding ground nearby by shrine parishioners dressed as warriors.
At the annual festival on October 16, kurabeuma (horse racing) is presented at the horse-riding grounds nearby and the shrine parishioners dress as samurai.
At the annual festival on October 16, kurabeuma (horse racing) is presented at the horse-riding grounds nearby and the shrine parishioners dress as samurai.
